page.title: 06SHERE CHURCH 1
page.content: There has been a church on the present site since Saxon times and this was recorded in the Domesday Book. The church as it stands today was built in the 12th century and was dedicated to St.James,patron saint of pilgrims,who used to stop at Shere on their way to Canterbury. The church has a bell tower with a ring of eight bells and a 13th century timber frame spire which is considered to be one of the first in England. The organ and choir stalls were originally sited in the chancel and were moved to the south aisle in 1967. There are several monumental brasses in the floor and walls of the church. These include a 15th century brass of Robert Scarlif,a former rector of Shere. The font is about seven hundred years old,it is made of Purbeck marble
